title: Reflux (Children)
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Spitting up , also known as reflux or gastroesophageal reflux ( GER ), is messy. But unlike vomiting , it usually isn't painful, and babies often don't even notice they're spitting up. It is more concerning to the parents than the baby. If your baby’s spit up goes beyond a simple throw up, they could be showing signs of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Most babies outgrow reflux by 11-12 months of age.

sections.heading: Call Doctor If Your Child:
bullets: Spits up brown, red, or green fluid
Vomits or spits up forcefully every time
Vomits and then has trouble breathing or is choking
Won't eat or isn't gaining weight
Cries frequently
Wets fewer diapers than usual
Is very drowsy or tired
Has trouble breathing

sections.heading: 1. When Feeding
bullets: Feed your baby in an upright position, not while they are lying down.
Burp your child every three to five minutes, especially if bottle feeding , make sure you burp your baby before switching to the other breast if breast feeding .
If the doctor has seen your child, they may recommend thickening each ounce of formula with one tablespoon of rice cereal. You may need to enlarge the bottle's nipple.
If formula-feeding, discuss changing the formula with your pediatrician if spitting up is a big concern.

sections.heading: 2. After Feeding
bullets: Avoid feeding your child after your child has spit up. Wait until the next scheduled feeding time.
Ask your pediatrician whether your child is nursing for the right length of time or if the bottles are the correct size and make sure you are not over feeding.
Keep your child upright for 30 minutes after feedings, and try to keep them as relatively still as you can.
